title: How to Make Butternut Squash Fries

steps.headline: Heat the oil to the proper temperature.
steps.description: Add 1 quart (946 ml) of vegetable oil to a large, heavy-bottomed pot. Attach a deep fry thermometer to the pot, and heat the oil over medium-high until it reaches 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius). You can substitute peanut oil for the vegetable oil if you prefer. A candy thermometer will also work to monitor the temperature of the oil.

steps.headline: Cut the squash into sticks.
steps.description: For the fries, you’ll need 1 butternut squash that’s been peeled and seeded. Use a sharp knife to slice it into sticks that are approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. A vegetable peeler works well to remove the skin from the butternut squash. To remove the seeds from inside the squash, you usually only need a regular spoon.

steps.headline: Fry the squash in the oil in batches until golden brown.
steps.description: Once the oil is hot enough and you’ve cut the butternut squash, add the fries to the oil in batches. Allow the squash to cook until they become golden brown and crisp, which should take approximately 3 to 5 minutes. Be careful not to add too many fries to the oil at once or the temperature may drop. Use a wooden spoon to stir the fries gently while they’re frying. That will help ensure that they cook evenly on all sides.

steps.headline: Drain the fries on paper towel.
steps.description: When the butternut squash fries are golden brown and crisp, use a slotted wooden spoon to lift them out of the oil. Transfer them to a plate lined with paper towel to get rid of the excess oil.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the warm fries with salt and serve.
steps.description: After you’ve drained the butternut squash fries, place them on a platter. Season them with kosher salt to taste, and serve while they are still warm. You can serve the fries with ketchup or your favorite fry dipping sauce.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and grease the baking sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries, set the temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius) and allow it to preheat. Next, use a nonstick cooking spray to grease a baking sheet so the fries won’t stick. You can also use a broiler pan to bake the fries if you prefer.

steps.headline: Cut the squash into sticks.
steps.description: The fries require 1 large butternut squash that has been peeled and seeded. Use a sharp knife to cut the squash into sticks that that are approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. If you like, you can use a crinkle cutter tool to create crinkle cut butternut squash fries rather than traditional straight fries.

steps.headline: Blot the squash and sprinkle with salt.
steps.description: After you’ve cut the squash into fries, use clean paper towel to gently blot the excess moisture from them. Next, season the fries with ⅛ teaspoon (1 g) of coarse salt or more if desired, and toss to ensure that the squash is evenly coated. If you like, you can add other seasonings to the butternut squash fries. Black pepper, cayenne pepper, onion powder, garlic powder, and paprika are all tasty options.

steps.headline: Place the fries on the baking sheet and bake them for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Once the fries are seasoned, spread them out on the greased baking sheet. Place them in the preheated oven and allow them to bake for 20 minutes. Make sure that the fries are in a single layer on the baking sheet so they will bake evenly.

steps.headline: Turn the fries over and continue baking until they are crisp.
steps.description: After the fries have baked for 20 minutes, flip them over with a spatula. Let the fries bake for another 20 minutes, or until they are crispy on the outside.

steps.headline: Serve the fries while warm.
steps.description: When the fries are finished baking, transfer them to a platter. Enjoy the fries while they are still warm. You can dip the baked butternut squash fries in ketchup, ranch dressing, herbed mayo, or your favorite dipping sauce.

methods.name: Whipping Up Parmesan Butternut Squash Fries

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the baking sheet.
steps.description: Set the oven temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius), and let it fully heat. Next, spray a wire cooling rack with nonstick cooking spray and set it on a baking sheet. If you don’t have a cooling rack, line a baking sheet with foil and grease the surface with the cooking spray.

steps.headline: Toss the butternut squash with the oil and seasonings.
steps.description: For the fries, you’ll need 1 medium butternut squash that’s been peeled, seeded, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks. Place the sticks in a bowl and add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried thyme, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried oregano, a pinch of cayenne pepper, and kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Mix well so the fries are completely coated. You can other seasonings to the fries if you like. Garlic powder, dried basil, and crushed red pepper are some options to consider.

steps.headline: Spread the fries out on the cooling rack and bake until they are crisp.
steps.description: When the fries are seasoned, transfer them to the cooling rack on the baking sheet. Place them in the preheated oven and allow them to cook until they are golden brown and crisp, which should take 25 to 30 minutes. Halfway through the baking, flip the fries over so they cook evenly on both sides.

steps.headline: Transfer the fries to a platter and top with the Parmesan and chives.
steps.description: When the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Place them on a platter, and sprinkle ¼ cup (25 g) of freshly grated Parmesan cheese over the fries. Next, garnish the fries with 2 tablespoon (6 g) of chopped fresh chives and serve. A garlic aioli or herbed mayo makes a good dipping sauce for the Parmesan butternut squash fries.

text: Frying Classic Butternut Squash Fries Heat the oil to the proper temperature. Add 1 quart (946 ml) of vegetable oil to a large, heavy-bottomed pot. Attach a deep fry thermometer to the pot, and heat the oil over medium-high until it reaches 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius). You can substitute peanut oil for the vegetable oil if you prefer. A candy thermometer will also work to monitor the temperature of the oil. Cut the squash into sticks. For the fries, you’ll need 1 butternut squash that’s been peeled and seeded. Use a sharp knife to slice it into sticks that are approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. A vegetable peeler works well to remove the skin from the butternut squash. To remove the seeds from inside the squash, you usually only need a regular spoon. Fry the squash in the oil in batches until golden brown. Once the oil is hot enough and you’ve cut the butternut squash, add the fries to the oil in batches. Allow the squash to cook until they become golden brown and crisp, which should take approximately 3 to 5 minutes. Be careful not to add too many fries to the oil at once or the temperature may drop. Use a wooden spoon to stir the fries gently while they’re frying. That will help ensure that they cook evenly on all sides. Drain the fries on paper towel. When the butternut squash fries are golden brown and crisp, use a slotted wooden spoon to lift them out of the oil. Transfer them to a plate lined with paper towel to get rid of the excess oil. Sprinkle the warm fries with salt and serve. After you’ve drained the butternut squash fries, place them on a platter. Season them with kosher salt to taste, and serve while they are still warm. You can serve the fries with ketchup or your favorite fry dipping sauce. Preparing Baked Butternut Squash Fries Preheat the oven and grease the baking sheet. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the fries, set the temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius) and allow it to preheat. Next, use a nonstick cooking spray to grease a baking sheet so the fries won’t stick. You can also use a broiler pan to bake the fries if you prefer. Cut the squash into sticks. The fries require 1 large butternut squash that has been peeled and seeded. Use a sharp knife to cut the squash into sticks that that are approximately ½-inch (13-mm) thick. If you like, you can use a crinkle cutter tool to create crinkle cut butternut squash fries rather than traditional straight fries. Blot the squash and sprinkle with salt. After you’ve cut the squash into fries, use clean paper towel to gently blot the excess moisture from them. Next, season the fries with ⅛ teaspoon (1 g) of coarse salt or more if desired, and toss to ensure that the squash is evenly coated. If you like, you can add other seasonings to the butternut squash fries. Black pepper, cayenne pepper, onion powder, garlic powder, and paprika are all tasty options. Place the fries on the baking sheet and bake them for 20 minutes. Once the fries are seasoned, spread them out on the greased baking sheet. Place them in the preheated oven and allow them to bake for 20 minutes. Make sure that the fries are in a single layer on the baking sheet so they will bake evenly. Turn the fries over and continue baking until they are crisp. After the fries have baked for 20 minutes, flip them over with a spatula. Let the fries bake for another 20 minutes, or until they are crispy on the outside. Serve the fries while warm. When the fries are finished baking, transfer them to a platter. Enjoy the fries while they are still warm. You can dip the baked butternut squash fries in ketchup, ranch dressing, herbed mayo, or your favorite dipping sauce. Whipping Up Parmesan Butternut Squash Fries Preheat the oven and prepare the baking sheet. Set the oven temperature to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius), and let it fully heat. Next, spray a wire cooling rack with nonstick cooking spray and set it on a baking sheet. If you don’t have a cooling rack, line a baking sheet with foil and grease the surface with the cooking spray. Toss the butternut squash with the oil and seasonings. For the fries, you’ll need 1 medium butternut squash that’s been peeled, seeded, and cut into ½-inch (13-mm) thick sticks. Place the sticks in a bowl and add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried thyme, ½ teaspoon (½ g) of dried oregano, a pinch of cayenne pepper, and kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste. Mix well so the fries are completely coated. You can other seasonings to the fries if you like. Garlic powder, dried basil, and crushed red pepper are some options to consider. Spread the fries out on the cooling rack and bake until they are crisp. When the fries are seasoned, transfer them to the cooling rack on the baking sheet. Place them in the preheated oven and allow them to cook until they are golden brown and crisp, which should take 25 to 30 minutes. Halfway through the baking, flip the fries over so they cook evenly on both sides. Transfer the fries to a platter and top with the Parmesan and chives. When the fries are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Place them on a platter, and sprinkle ¼ cup (25 g) of freshly grated Parmesan cheese over the fries. Next, garnish the fries with 2 tablespoon (6 g) of chopped fresh chives and serve. A garlic aioli or herbed mayo makes a good dipping sauce for the Parmesan butternut squash fries.
